Award.AbstractNarration:
At the dawn of the universe, just an instant after the Big Bang, everything that now exists was packed into an incredibly tiny space - a space that was expanding like a balloon in every direction at the speed of light. For these first few moments, the entire universe was made of a substance known as quark-gluon plasma, a soup of elementary particles that soon coalesced into the larger particles, and finally the atoms that we know today.

This research focuses on the re-creation of these conditions at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider in New York and the Large Hadron Collider in Europe. These colliders smash nuclei together, producing tiny fleeting quantities of quark gluon plasma. By studying the fluid characteristics of this plasma using mathematical models, we hope to explain what is seen at these massive colliders. By extension, this knowledge will help us understand what the early universe was like and how it came to be what it is today. I am especially excited to be sharing this research with disadvantaged students in Detroit through a program aimed at students who are studying to become teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project represented an integrated program of research and education at Wayne State University. The research aim is to further develop theoretical techniques to describe the dynamics of relativistic heavy ion collisions in experiments at the Relativistic Heavy Ion Collider (RHIC) and the Large Hadron Collider (LHC). The educational goal includes efforts to help the disadvantaged youth of metropolitan Detroit by improving science literacy and enriching teacher education.

Intellectual Merit: Relativistic heavy ion collisions can create tiny short-lived samples of quark gluon plasma. As the LHC explores the high energy frontier with ion as well as proton collisions, RHIC experiments are beginning to quantitatively characterize the properties of the plasma. These efforts require close ties between experimenters and theorists to overcome the fact that the plasma must rapidly coalesce back into hadrons.

Two particle correlation measurements and related fluctuation studies can reveal space-time information about particle production and dynamics not measured by single particle observables. This project centers on an innovative program to develop theoretical tools for the analysis of correlations in a hydrodynamic context. Applications of this framework to transverse-momentum fluctuation data previously provided a first estimate of the shear viscosity. Extensions of the method have show that the data is consistent with a realistic temperature-dependent viscosity and a lattice QCD equation of state. Predictions were made for LHC. Importantly, the hydrodynamic model further predicts a dip in the rapidity dependence of the momentum-current correlations that is absent from density correlations. Observation of such a dip provides new information that can settle debates over the nature of higher order corrections to relativistic dissipative hydrodynamics.

Angular correlations exhibit a rich landscape of ridges and valleys, some of which persist over a long range in rapidity.  This project included efforts to apply our hydrodynamic framework to understand this landscape. Combined with anisotropic flow and fluctuation measurements, these efforts promise to reveal information on both early stages of particle production -- the Glasma -- as well as the later period of hydrodynamic evolution.  It was shown that initial state fluctuations in concert with later-stage hydrodynamic flow describes a range of observables including both even and odd flow harmonics, the ridge, and multiplicity, momentum and flow fluctuations. Moreover, Glasma correlations are consistent with distinctive dependence on the beam energy and projectile mass dependence (through the so-called saturation scale) for a wide range of observables.

Broader Impacts: Educational efforts provide for substantial participation of undergraduate and graduate students in research. Involvement with Wayne State's extensive NSF Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program attracts under-represented students to nuclear physics. This program promotes undergraduate interest in careers in science, technology and engineering, especially among the underrepresented. In addition, proposed here is the continued development of an ambitious outreach initiative to encourage scientific literacy and public perception of the scientific method.
